titlestmt.title: Experimental Relief Plate Copy 2: electronic edition

Editors: Morris Eaves, University of

filedesc.extent:
1 XML file approx. 17KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC
10918) files ranging in size from 177KB to 1600KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC LibrariesNovember 2019
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of nineteen separate prints designed and etched or engraved by Blake. The original works are housed in seven collections, including the Bodleian Library, British Museum, Robert N. Essick collection, Fitzwilliam Museum, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and National Gallery of Art, Washington. These separate prints join two others, Deaths Door and George Cumberland’s Card, and four series of prints, all previously published, to complete this important category of Blake's endeavors as a printmaker.
The new group of nineteen includes Blake’s first separate engraving, Joseph of Arimathea among the Rocks of Albion, executed while still an apprentice, and two of his masterpieces in mixed-method etching/engraving, the large Job and Ezekiel plates. The Accusers of Theft Adultery Murder, Lucifer and the Pope in Hell, and Albion rose depict Blake's response to the political revolutions of the late eighteenth century. Blake printed these three, plus A Dream of Thiralatha and Joseph of Arimathea Preaching to the Inhabitants of Britain, in colors as part of his development of relief and planographic color printing in the mid-1790s. Other plates, ranging from The Approach of Doom to the Enoch lithograph and The Chaining of Orc, testify to Blake's lifelong experimentation with innovative graphic techniques. He produced Deaths Door and the Virgil Relief Etching as book illustrations but they were never published as such and exist only as unique, separate impressions. Introductions to each work offer information on medium, changes in state, dating, and subject. Blake’s Laocoön etching/engraving, sometimes considered a separate plate, is included among the Illuminated Books in the Archive.
Late in his career, c. 1820-25 or even extending into his final year, Blake returned to several of his earlier separate engravings, dramatically revising the interplay of darkness and light in their designs and adding new inscriptions on some plates that alter their meaning. These final states of Joseph of Arimathea among the Rocks of Albion, Job, Ezekiel, The Accusers, Albion rose, and Blake's largest and most ambitious print, Chaucers Canterbury Pilgrims, are included, along with extant earlier states. The publication of these and other multiple states and printings offer insights into Blake's development as a printmaker and changes in his thematic interests over several decades.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objinfo.medium: relief etching, possibly with a few touches of white-line etching
objinfo.printingstyle: intaglioIn this impression the recessed, etched areas are inked and printed. Accordingly, the relief plateaus appear as white areas. This is the reverse of normal relief printing and constitutes an odd type of intaglio inking and printing.
objinfo.pennednumbers: noneThe work is inscribed lower left in pencil, "W. Blake fecit". This inscription is not by Blake.

provenance.name: National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.
provenance.note: Probably the untitled "Blake print" acquired by the dealer Charles Sessler in Feb. 1951 from "Nicholson" for $48 and sold to Carl Zigrosser for $60 in Nov. 1951 (according to Sessler's business records); given by Zigrosser to Lessing J. Rosenwald in June 1961 and presented by Rosenwald in 1964 to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.

repository.institution: National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.

desc.objtitle:
Experimental Relief Plate Let Him Look Up into the Heavens & Laugh in the Bright Air,
Object 1 (Essick XIV)

objnote.p: This print is sometimes called "Let Him Look Up into the Heavens & Laugh in the Bright Air." The actual subject is not known.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This experimental relief plate has three main sections. The upper portion of the plate depicts a nude male figure who faces forward and is visible from the shoulders down. The figure may sit on a small mound or kneel on his bent right knee. His left leg is bent and in front of his body. The figure's left arm is bent and he appears to grasp a severed human head that faces up and right with his left hand at right. The figure's left arm is either not visible or distorted to appear more snake-like against his body at left. A bird with outstretched wings flies in an area of sky in the upper left corner of the design, and an indeterminate form is visible below and right of the bird. A cat is visible below the severed head at right. Lines and other forms on the ground below the figure may indicate grass or other vegetation. Additional indeterminate vegetation may be visible above the figure's hand at right. The middle section of the plate is smaller than the surrounding designs and depicts a series of geometric and linear designs. The top row of designs includes a triangle at left, a circle at center, and a square at right, as well as several linear forms in between and around the row. A shape suggesting a crescent moon is visible below the square at right. A semi-circular line surrounds the lower portion of the middle section. Both straight and squiggled lines are visible inside the semi-circle. Like the upper portion, the third, lowest portion of the plate depicts a nude male figure who faces forward and is visible from the shoulders down. The figure appears to sit on grassy ground or kneel on his right knee; his body is twisted or bent to the left. His left leg is bent forward. His right arm is bent and at his side with his left hand braced against the ground at left. His left arm is bent at a right angle and his left hand is also braced on the ground or a rock at right. Below his left hand, two severed heads that face forward are visible in the lower right corner. Additional indeterminate vegetation may be visible above the figure's hand at right. Horizontal lines to the left and right of the figure's torso may suggest beams of light in a background sky.

component.illusobjdesc: The upper portion of the plate depicts a nude male figure who faces forward and is visible from the shoulders down. The figure may sit on a small mound or kneel on his bent right knee. His left leg is bent and in front of his body with his left foot prominent. The figure's left arm is bent. The figure appears to grasp a severed human head that faces up and right with his left hand at right. The figure's left arm is either not visible or distorted to appear more snake-like against his body at left.

The figure in the upper portion of the design may grasp a severed head that is visible near the right edge of the plate. The head has long, curly hair and faces forward and up. Its mouth appears to be open.
A bird with outstretched wings flies in an area of sky in the upper left corner of the design, and an indeterminate form is visible below and right of the bird.
A cat is visible below the severed head near the right edge of the design. The cat sits facing forward and left.

Lines and other forms on the ground below the figure may indicate grass or other vegetation. Additional indeterminate vegetation may be visible above the figure's left hand at right and below the figure's right hand at left.
The figure may sit on a small mound. The bird flying in the upper left corner may suggest an area of sky.

The middle section of the plate is smaller than the surrounding designs and depicts a series of geometric and linear designs. The top row of designs includes a triangle at left, a circle at center, and a square at right, as well as several linear forms in between and around the row. A shape suggesting a crescent moon is visible below the square at right. A semi-circular line surrounds the lower portion of the middle section. Both straight and squiggled lines are visible inside the semi-circle.

Like the upper portion, the third, lowest portion of the plate depicts a nude male figure who faces forward and is visible from the shoulders down. The figure appears to sit on grassy ground or kneel on his right knee; his body is slightly twisted or bent to the left. His left leg is bent forward and his left foot is prominent. His right arm is bent and at his side with his left hand braced against the ground at left. His left arm is bent at a right angle and his left hand is also braced on the ground or a rock at right.

Below the figure's left hand, two severed heads that face forward are visible in the lower right corner. The head at right appears to have an open mouth. The head at left faces slightly left and has curly hair. The head on the left may be female; the head on the right may be male.
The figure in the lower section of the design appears to sit on grassy ground. Additional indeterminate vegetation may be visible above the figure's hand at right.

The lower figure appears to brace his hands against the ground or stones both at left and right. Horizontal lines to the left and right of the figure's torso may suggest beams of light in a background sky.
